Lord Haldane was photographed aboard the Lusitania on August 29, when it arrived in New York harbor. He lingered on board to grant interviews to the New York press.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I'm still inclined to think the scale and decoration are that of a liner and not of an elegant steam yacht. The steps with a woman on in the background don't look like a yacht to me. The Corsair used for the trip up river would have been Corsair III, which became the USS Oceanographer after his death en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Oceanographer_%28AGS-3%29 She was over 300 ft long but only 33 ft wide. This side deck would have been a substantial percentage of that. I've just found www.navsource.org/archives/09/10/1003.htm with a 1916 picture of the Corsair (after requisition for WWI service). She has many more windows and no light paint on her superstructure. www.navsource.org/archives/09/10/09100304.jpg

comment._content: Wystan, I do note the dates, but we both know that the dates can relate to date of use rather than date of capture. This just doesn't look as though it could be on the Corsair in the 1916 photo. So here's the result of a different line of investigation -- looking for pictures of the Lusitania that might have windows like these. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2515735403/ If you look at the high-res TIFF and zoom in at the upper deck under the aft funnel, you will see windows with these same curved upper panes (highlighted by the snow).

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: By thunder, swanq, it looks like you've nailed it! The evidence here is most persuasive. You have convinced me that the Lusitania was the setting of Haldane's shipboard portraits. The New York Times story of August 30, 1913, explains that reporters (and presumably, photographers) came aboard the Lusitania on August 29, as it was detained briefly in quarantine [at Ellis Island(?)] before docking in New York Harbor. Viscount Haldane was affable, even humorous, as he allowed himself to be interviewed by the press. That would have been when the Bain cameraman had his chance to shoot the full-figure pose and the two closeups. New York Times story, August 30: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E05E4DC113CE6...
